author: potuz
content: I don't think there's much difference in any number. My take on this is that it doesn't matter what we choose, it has to be some number, and it's fine if it's arbitrary. The only thing that actually matters is the total issuance that needs to be optimized over time to be the minimum needed to maintain security. The only worry with the source timely flag to me is that it is one of the points where existing validators may start loosing rewards (compared to what they were earning before). As we are sure to see less performance after the merge, and currently they get the source reward for free.

author: jgm
content: My main worry is that after the merge the execution layer rewards will outweigh the individual consensus layer rewards by a significant margin, which will cause a shift in terms of focus for validators.    As such, it may be required to increase the consensus rewards (or perhaps alter the reward rules) to ensure that the consensus protocol doesn't become a toy that can be played with to increase execution layer rewards.

author: potuz
content: I think this is an impossible problem to solve: in principle after the merge we can have zero non-MEV rewards for the execution part, I agree that the MEV rewards may outweigh the consensus layer rewards and this is problematic, but increasing the consensus layer rewards to counteract this will not solve anything

author: jgm
content: On an unrelated note: the latest devnet seems to have the same sync committees for periods 0 (epochs 0 through 255) and 1 (epochs 256 through 511).  Period 0 included the HF epoch (10).  Not sure if this is to be expected, or if I have mucked something up.

author: jgm
content: (Also, period 2 had a different committee).

author: jgm
content: It's more of a question of balance.  And as mentioned it may be that a harsher/stricter set of rules need to come in to play for the consensus layer to keep clients in line.

author: jgm
content:
Regarding the sync committees:  there is the following note in the spec:
```
# Note: A duplicate committee is assigned for the current and next committee at genesis
```
And although not genesis, as the HF occurred in the first sync committee period I assume that this is why it happened.

Given that this will not be the situation on mainnet I wonder if it's worth a quick devnet that doesn't enact the hard fork until after the first sync committee period has expired (so fork at e.g. epoch 266)?

author: ajsutton
content: I‚Äôd say that note is ‚Äúwrong‚Äù in that the first two sync committees are always the same. It doesn‚Äôt matter if they are at genesis or block a million.

author: jgm
content: Interesting.  I only had a quick glance through the spec but didn't see where this is defined.  Could you point me to the relevant bit of the spec?  Ta.

author: ajsutton
content: ooo, specific part of spec is hard. The key thing is that the committees are randomly selected using the randao - normally they're selected one sync committee period ahead of time, but the first two are created at the same time, so they use the same randao for randomness so they select the same committee.

author: ajsutton
content:
ah the comment in https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/blob/dev/specs/altair/fork.md#upgrading-the-state is right:
```
    # Note: A duplicate committee is assigned for the current and next committee at the fork boundary
```
